title: Single base pair mutations, Sickle Cell

content.question: Directions: Answers must be in essay form. Outline form is not acceptable. Labeled diagrams may be used to supplement discussion, but in no case will a diagram alone suffice. It is important that you read each question completely before you begin. Certain human genetic conditions, such as sickle cell anemia, result from single base pair mutations in DNA. (a) Explain how a single base-pair mutant in DNA can alter the structure and, in some cases, the function of a protein.

frqParts.text: Directions: Answers must be in essay form. Outline form is not acceptable. Labeled diagrams may be used to supplement discussion, but in no case will a diagram alone suffice. It is important that you read each question completely before you begin. Certain human genetic conditions, such as sickle cell anemia, result from single base pair mutations in DNA. (a) Explain how a single base-pair mutant in DNA can alter the structure and, in some cases, the function of a protein.
(b) Explain, using a specific example, the potential consequences of the production of a mutant protein to the structure and function of the cells of an organism.
(c) Describe how the frequency of an allele coding for a mutant protein may increase in a population over time.
